name: Usher
description:
'''Usher Raymond IV''' (born October 14, 1978) is an American singer, songwriter, dancer, and actor. He is recognized as an influential figure in [[contemporary R&B]] and [[pop music]]. In 1994, Usher released his [[Usher (album)|self-titled debut album]] at the age of 15. He rose to fame with the release of his second album, ''[[My Way (Usher album)|My Way]]'' (1997), which spawned his first US [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] number-one single "[[Nice & Slow]]", and the top-two singles: the [[My Way (Usher song)|title track]] and "[[You Make Me Wanna...]]".

Usher's third album, ''[[8701]]'' (2001), saw continued success, selling eight million copies and yielding the US number-one singles, "[[U Remind Me]]" and "[[U Got It Bad]]". His fourth album, ''[[Confessions (Usher album)|Confessions]]'' (2004), sold over [[List of fastest-selling albums#United States|one million copies first-week]] and was supported by four consecutive US number-one singles: "[[Yeah! (Usher song)|Yeah!]]", "[[Burn (Usher song)|Burn]]", "[[Confessions Part II]]", and "[[My Boo (Usher and Alicia Keys song)|My Boo]]". The album sold over [[List of best-selling albums of the 21st century|15 million copies worldwide]] and received a diamond certification from the [[Recording Industry Association of America]] (RIAA). After splitting from his manager and mother [[Jonnetta Patton]] in 2007, he released the album ''[[Here I Stand (Usher album)|Here I Stand]]'' (2008), which spawned the number-one single "[[Love in This Club]]". ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' named him the second [[Billboard Decade-End#2000s|most successful artist of the decade]], the number-one Hot 100 artist of the decade, and ranked ''Confessions'' as the top solo album of the decade.

Usher's sixth album, ''[[Raymond v. Raymond]]'' (2010), contained his ninth number-one single, "[[OMG (Usher song)|OMG]]", making him one of the few artists to top the ''Billboard'' Hot 100 in three consecutive decades. His debut [[extended play]], ''[[Versus (Usher EP)|Versus]]'' (2010), produced the top-five single "[[DJ Got Us Fallin' in Love]]". Usher's seventh album, ''[[Looking 4 Myself]]'' (2012) saw further [[electronic music|electronic]] production and spawned the top-ten single "[[Scream (Usher song)|Scream]]". He followed it with the albums ''[[Hard II Love]]'' (2016) and ''[[Coming Home (Usher album)|Coming Home]]'' (2024). His [[Super Bowl LVIII halftime show]] in 2024 drew 123 million viewers within the US.

Usher has sold over 100 million records worldwide, making him one of the [[List of best-selling music artists|best-selling music artists of all time]]. ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' ranked him among the [[Greatest Pop Stars of the 21st Century]]. His [[List of awards and nominations received by Usher|accolades]] include 8 [[Grammy Award]]s, 12 [[Soul Train Music Awards]], 8 [[American Music Award]]s, 18 [[Billboard Music Award|''Billboard'' Music Award]]s, 7 [[BET Awards]] (including the [[BET Lifetime Achievement Award]]) and a star on the [[Hollywood Walk of Fame]]. He was inducted into the [[Black Music & Entertainment Walk of Fame]] in 2021. In 2008, Usher co-founded the record label [[RBMG Records|Raymond-Braun Media Group (RBMG)]] with [[Scooter Braun]] to manage the career of singer [[Justin Bieber]]. Outside of music, he founded the charitable non-profit [[Usher's New Look]] in 1999, served as a coach on ''[[The Voice (American TV series)|The Voice]]'' (2013â€“2014), and starred in films such as ''[[The Faculty]]'' (1998), ''[[She's All That]]'' (1999), ''[[Light It Up (film)|Light It Up]]'' (1999), ''[[In the Mix (film)|In the Mix]]'' (2005) and ''[[Hands of Stone]]'' (2016).
